newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Spanish, Peru banks to bid on Banco de Venezuela.
newsitem.headline: Spanish, Peru banks to bid on Banco de Venezuela.

text.p: Spain's Banco Santander and Peru's Banco de Credito have placed a deposit which allows them to bid in Friday's auction for Venezuela's Banco de Venezuela, a top government official said Wednesday.

The two were the only banks to place the required $27.5 million deposit (10 percent of the minimum sale price) before the midnight on Tuesday deadline, the official from the state Deposit Guarantee Fund told Reuters.
Colombia's Banco Bogota and Germany's Dresdner Bank AG had also shown interest in the bank but failed to make the deposit necessary to take place in the auction, the official said.

The official said the fund could decide to postpone the auction to give other interested bidders more time to place their deposits. "We will decide today whether to extend the period," the official said.
The fund became the sole owner of Banco de Venezuela in August 1994 when the bank fell victim to a financial crisis.
The fund re-floated the bank which will be the first of four major banks slated for re-privatization to make it to auction.

Banco de Venezuela is the country's oldest bank and currently the third largest in terms of deposits. At the end of 1995 the bank's total assets were valued at 382 billion bolivars ($1.3 billion at the exchange rate at that time).
